question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

RECEIVED

1. **P** (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?): Given Elon Musk's prominence in the cryptocurrency community, there's a reasonable chance he may attend. However, attendance at events can be unpredictable, so I estimate a moderate probability.

2. **not_P** (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?): This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain probability, not_P will be 1 minus that probability.

3. **para_P** (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?): This is aligned with P, so I expect a similar probability, as both questions assess the same event.

4. **Q** (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?): This could be influenced by whether he attends or not, but it could also happen independently. I will estimate this with a slightly lower probability than P, as public statements can be made without attendance.

5. **P_and_Q** (Will both P and Q occur?): This requires both P and Q to be true. The probability will be lower than either P or Q alone, as both conditions must be met.

6. **P_or_Q** (Will either P or Q occur?): This encompasses both events. The probability will be higher than either event alone but will need to be calculated carefully to avoid exceeding 1.

7. **Q_and_not_P** (Will both Q and not_P occur?): This requires Q to happen while P does not. The probability will be less than Q, as it introduces the condition of not P.

8. **Q_given_P** (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?): This is a conditional probability. If P occurs, the likelihood of Q occurring should increase, but it won't be 100%. I will estimate this based on how likely Q is when P is true.

**Independence and Relationships:**
- P and Q are not entirely independent, as P's occurrence (Elon Musk attending) could influence the likelihood of Q (him making a statement). However, both can occur independently as well. 
- The relationships among the probabilities will need to adhere to the consistency rules provided, ensuring that the estimates do not contradict each other.

or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.50) <= 0.75 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.75 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.40 / 0.60 is FALSE

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be selected as the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other outcomes will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this case, we are evaluating the likelihood of Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The questions are interrelated, focusing on two main events: whether Musk will show up at the conference (P) and whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin (Q). 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This is a binary event that will resolve positively if Musk appears on stage at the conference. Given his previous engagements and interest in Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability of 0.65 for this event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P, so it will be estimated as 1 - P. Therefore, not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Chance of Elon Musk attending)**: This is similar to P, so I would assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin)**: Musk is known for his public statements regarding Bitcoin, so I would assign a probability of 0.70 for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The probability of both events happening together can be estimated as the product of the two probabilities, assuming some independence, so I would estimate this at 0.65 * 0.70 = 0.455.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This can be calculated using the formula: P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Therefore, it would be 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happens but not P)**: This is a bit trickier since it requires that Musk makes a statement without showing up. I would estimate this lower, around 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Q happens given P)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement is higher, so I would estimate this at around 0.85.

The relationships between P and Q suggest that they are not entirely independent since Musk's attendance may influence his likelihood of making a statement. I will ensure that these estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the events regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I consider the relationships between the various questions and how they interact with each other under the provided consistency rules. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This is a binary event that can be influenced by Musk's schedule and interest in the event. Given his previous involvement in Bitcoin discussions, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P. Since P is estimated at a certain probability, not_P should equal 1 - P. This relationship is straightforward and adheres to the negation rule.

3. **para_P (Chance Musk will attend)**: This is similar to P, and I expect it to be equal to P since both questions assess the same event from different angles.

4. **Q (Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This event is somewhat independent of P, as Musk could make a statement even if he does not attend. However, the likelihood of him making a statement may be higher if he is present, so I estimate a moderate probability.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur)**: This is a conjunction of P and Q. The probability of both occurring should be less than or equal to the probability of either occurring individually. Thus, I need to ensure that the estimate for P_and_Q is consistent with the individual probabilities of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs)**: This is the union of P and Q. The probability of either event happening should be greater than or equal to the maximum of P and Q and less than or equal to the sum of both probabilities. This needs careful consideration to ensure it fits within the defined bounds.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Musk makes a statement but does not show up)**: This is another conjunction that requires careful balancing, as it can occur if Musk makes a statement without attending. I estimate this probability based on the independence of Q from P.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will he make a statement)**: This conditional probability should reflect the likelihood of Q occurring if P is true. It can be estimated based on the assumption that if Musk attends, he is likely to make a statement, so this probability should be higher than the unconditional Q.

In summary, I will ensure that all these probabilities are interrelated and conform to the consistency rules provided. This means adjusting values to ensure the negation, conjunction, and disjunction rules are satisfied while maintaining logical relationships between the events.

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities of several events related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. Here’s a breakdown of the reasoning for each prediction:

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This probability will depend on various factors such as Musk's schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and public engagement. Given his history with Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain probability, then not_P will be 1 - P.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is similar to P, and I would expect it to be the same since it is essentially asking the same question in a different way.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This probability is somewhat independent of whether he shows up or not, as he could make a statement without being physically present at the conference. However, his presence might increase the likelihood of making a statement.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability will be lower than either P or Q alone since it requires both events to happen. I will estimate it based on the individual probabilities of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is a broader event that combines the probabilities of P and Q occurring. I will use the formula for the union of two events to calculate this.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs but not P)**: This scenario requires that Musk makes a statement without showing up. This is a specific case and may have a lower probability than both P and Q happening together.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P)**: This conditional probability will be based on the likelihood of Q occurring if P is true. If he shows up, the probability of him making a statement should increase.

In terms of consistency, I need to ensure that:
- The relationship between P and not_P is complementary.
- The relationships between P, Q, and their combinations (P_and_Q, P_or_Q, etc.) adhere to the rules of probability.
- I will also ensure that my estimates for the probabilities do not violate any of the consistency rules outlined.

question.title: Will both Mike Pence and Ted Cruz be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Mike Pence and Ted Cruz are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If either or both are not selected, it will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities related to Elon Musk's potential attendance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The questions are interconnected, and we need to consider how they influence each other.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is central to the analysis. If he shows up, it could influence other questions positively, such as him making a public statement about Bitcoin.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the direct negation of P. The probabilities of P and not_P must sum to 1, which is a fundamental consistency rule. If we estimate P at a certain value, not_P is simply 1 minus that value.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is similar to P, and we can assign it the same probability as P due to their direct correlation.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is somewhat independent of P, but if P is true (he attends), it may increase the likelihood of Q being true as well.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both of the following occur: P and Q?)**: This question will resolve positively if both P and Q are true. The probability of this event will depend on the individual probabilities of P and Q, and it should follow the consistency rule for conjunctions.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: P or Q?)**: This is the disjunction of P and Q. The probability of this event must also obey the consistency rules, ensuring that it does not exceed the sum of the probabilities of P and Q.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both of the following occur: Q and not_P?)**: This question examines the scenario where Musk makes a statement about Bitcoin but does not attend the conference. This introduces a level of independence since Q can occur regardless of P.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that Musk shows up, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin?)**: This conditional question ties back to the relationship between P and Q. If P is true, it may affect the probability of Q positively.

In summary, the relationships among these questions are crucial for establishing their probabilities. We must ensure that our estimates are consistent with the rules provided, especially those related to negation, conjunction, and disjunction. Each probability must be interrelated according to the rules, ensuring that they do not contradict one another.

question.title: Will either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

For the predictions related to Elon Musk's potential attendance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I will consider various factors that may influence these probabilities. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Musk's history with Bitcoin and his influence in the cryptocurrency community, there is a reasonable chance he may attend. However, attendance at events can be unpredictable, so I would estimate a moderate probability for P, perhaps around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.65, then not_P would be 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is similar to P, so I would keep it at the same probability, 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Musk has made statements about Bitcoin in the past, and given the context of the conference, I would assign a probability of about 0.70 for him making a statement.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: For this to be true, Musk has to show up and make a statement. Assuming P and Q are somewhat independent, I would calculate this as P * Q, which is 0.65 * 0.70 = 0.455.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, it would be 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not P occurs?)**: This scenario requires that Musk makes a statement but does not show up. I would estimate this as Q * not_P, which would be 0.70 * 0.35 = 0.245.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement is likely higher. I would estimate this probability to be around 0.85.

After considering these factors, I will ensure that the probabilities adhere to the consistency rules provided.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

question.body:

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, AND will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination in the 2024 election cycle. If such a statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this resolves as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? This resolves as Yes if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves No otherwise.

This question will resolve as Yes if both (1) and (2) resolve as Yes.

For the question regarding Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, I have to consider several factors that influence the probability estimates for each variable. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is likely influenced by Musk's past involvement in Bitcoin events and his public persona. Given his previous appearances and engagement with the cryptocurrency community, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this event.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so its probability should directly relate to P's estimate. If P is high, not_P should be low.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is similar to P, so I would expect it to have a similar probability. 

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This could be influenced by the context of the event and Musk's current stance on Bitcoin at the time of the conference. Given his history of commenting on Bitcoin, I would estimate a moderate probability for this as well.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability is dependent on both P and Q. If either is low, this will also be low. I expect this to be lower than either P or Q individually due to the joint occurrence requirement.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, but I also need to ensure that it does not exceed 1. It should reflect the likelihood that at least one of the events happens.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur and not P?)**: This scenario is interesting because it would mean Musk makes a statement but does not attend. The probability of this happening should be lower than Q since it adds the condition of not P.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability should be higher than the overall probability of Q because if Musk is attending, he is more likely to make a statement as well.

After estimating these probabilities, I will ensure they adhere to the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between complementary events, joint probabilities, and conditional probabilities. question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President before July 15, 2024, or Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination for a Yes resolution. (b) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

In evaluating the probability estimates for the events related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I considered various factors that could influence each event's likelihood. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Musk's prominence in the Bitcoin community and his history of attending significant events, I estimate a relatively high probability for this event. However, the uncertainty surrounding his commitments and public engagements leads me to be cautious in my estimate.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40. This relationship is straightforward and follows the negation rule.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is effectively the same as P, so I would assign the same probability.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Considering Musk's active engagement with Bitcoin and social media, I would assign a moderate probability to this event occurring, as he often comments on Bitcoin-related topics.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This requires both events to happen. Given that these events are somewhat independent but can influence each other, I estimate this probability to be lower than either P or Q alone, reflecting the joint occurrence.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone since it encompasses both possibilities. I would calculate this using the appropriate formula for the union of probabilities.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while P does not?)**: This combines the likelihood of Musk making a statement without attending. Given the independence of these events, I would estimate this as a relatively low probability.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of Q happening if P has occurred. I would expect this to be higher than the unconditional probability of Q alone, as Musk making a public statement is likely if he attends the conference.

In summary, I will ensure that my estimates adhere to the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between complementary events (P and not_P), joint probabilities (P_and_Q), and conditional probabilities (Q_given_P). question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

In this scenario, we are analyzing various questions related to Elon Musk's attendance and statements during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key questions are: 

1. **P**: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? 
2. **not_P**: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? 
3. **para_P**: Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? 
4. **Q**: Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? 
5. **P_and_Q**: Will both P and Q occur? 
6. **P_or_Q**: Will either P or Q occur? 
7. **Q_and_not_P**: Will both Q and not_P occur? 
8. **Q_given_P**: Given that P occurs, will Q also occur? 

### Reasoning for Predictions:
- **P** and **not_P** are mutually exclusive events. If P is true, not_P must be false, and vice versa. Therefore, if I predict a high probability for P, I must predict a low probability for not_P, and vice versa.
- **para_P** is essentially a rephrased version of P, so it should have a similar probability estimate.
- **Q** is independent of P, as Musk could make a public statement about Bitcoin regardless of his attendance. However, there may be some correlation due to the context of the event.
- **P_and_Q** will depend on both P and Q being true. Thus, its probability should be lower than both P and Q but can be calculated based on their individual probabilities.
- **P_or_Q** should have a higher probability than either P or Q alone because it covers the scenario where either event occurs.
- **Q_and_not_P** will depend on Q being true while P is false, which introduces a correlation that needs to be taken into account.
- **Q_given_P** will typically have a higher probability than Q alone since if Musk is present, he is more likely to make a statement.

### Consistency Rules:
I will ensure that the estimates respect the consistency rules provided:
- **neg**: P + not_P = 1
- **andor**: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q
- **and**: P_and_Q must be within the bounds defined by P and Q.
- **or**: P_or_Q must be within the bounds defined by P and Q.
- **but**: P must equal P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P.
- **cond**: P must approximate P_and_Q / Q_given_P.
- **para**: P must equal para_P.

Given these relationships, I will estimate probabilities that reflect realistic expectations based on the context of the event and the nature of Musk's involvement with Bitcoin.

P: 0.65,

para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.40,
P_or_Q: 0.75,

cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.40 / 0.55 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P and will be calculated as 1 - P. The likelihood of him not attending is influenced by various factors, including his schedule and interest in Bitcoin events.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This probability is aligned with P, as it essentially asks the same question. Therefore, it will have the same probability estimate as P.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference)**: This question evaluates whether Musk will publicly discuss Bitcoin, independent of his attendance. Given his history with Bitcoin, I estimate this probability to be moderate.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability represents the scenario where Musk both attends the conference and makes a public statement about Bitcoin. Since both events are related, this probability will be less than or equal to both P and Q, reflecting their joint occurrence.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability captures the likelihood of either Musk attending the conference or making a public statement. It should be higher than P and Q individually, as it combines the probabilities of both events.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This scenario evaluates whether Musk makes a statement while not attending. This probability must be calculated carefully, considering the independence of Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P)**: This conditional probability assesses whether Musk will make a statement if he attends the conference. It typically will be higher than Q alone, as attending the event might increase the likelihood of him speaking.

By ensuring that the estimates adhere to the consistency rules, we can establish a coherent framework for these probabilities. Each probability is interrelated, and adjustments in one will affect the others, particularly in the context of the logical relationships defined by the consistency rules.

para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.60,
P_and_Q: 0.50,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.10,
Q_given_P: 0.77

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.75 + 0.50 - 0.60 is TRUE

but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.75 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.77 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). It resolves NO if either condition is not met. Note that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution of condition (b).

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

(b) Resolves YES if Biden does not remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This includes if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several probabilities related to Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The questions revolve around whether he will attend the conference, whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin, and the relationships between these events. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability will depend on various factors, including Musk's schedule and interest in Bitcoin at that time. Given his previous engagements and interest in cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate probability, say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P. If P is 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Since this is essentially the same question as P, I would assign it the same probability of 0.60.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is somewhat independent of P, as he could make a statement without attending. Given his history of discussing Bitcoin publicly, I estimate this probability to be around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability is dependent on both P and Q. If we assume P and Q are independent, we can calculate it as P * Q = 0.60 * 0.50 = 0.30.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. So, 0.60 + 0.50 - 0.30 = 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This is a more complex relationship, but if we assume that Q can happen independently of P, we can estimate it as Q * not_P = 0.50 * 0.40 = 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability that would likely be higher than Q alone, given that if Musk is present, he might be inclined to make a statement. I would estimate this at around 0.70.

Overall, these estimates must respect the consistency rules provided. I will ensure that the calculated values for P_and_Q, P_or_Q, Q_and_not_P, and Q_given_P are coherent with the values of P, not_P, and Q.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a direct question about Musk's attendance. Given his past involvement in cryptocurrency discussions and events, I estimate a moderate probability of around 0.60 for this event, reflecting a reasonable chance of his appearance.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complementary event to P. Therefore, it should be 1 - P. If P is 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a rephrased version of P, so it should have the same probability estimate as P, which is 0.60.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Musk's history of making public statements about Bitcoin and his general interest in cryptocurrencies, I estimate this probability to be around 0.70.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either occur: Musk shows up or makes a statement?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. So, it would be 0.60 + 0.70 - 0.42 = 0.88.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: Musk makes a statement and does not show up?)**: This is a bit tricky since it involves a contradiction if P and Q are both true. I estimate this to be lower, around 0.20, considering that if he makes a statement, he might also show up.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will he make a statement?)**: This conditional probability should be relatively high, as if he attends, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I estimate this to be around 0.85.

In summary, the relationships between these probabilities are consistent with the rules provided. The estimates reflect reasonable assumptions based on Musk's previous behavior and public persona in relation to Bitcoin.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In predicting the probabilities for the events related to Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I will consider the interdependencies between the questions as well as the implications of each event on the others. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's general interest in Bitcoin and previous engagements at similar events. Given his public persona, I might estimate a moderate probability for this event, say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it should be around 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it should align closely with it, likely around 0.60.

4. **Q (Elon Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This event is somewhat independent but could be influenced by whether he attends the conference. However, even if he doesn't attend, he might still make a statement, so I would estimate this probability to be around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This is dependent on both P and Q being true. If I estimate P at 0.60 and Q at 0.50, I might estimate this joint probability conservatively at around 0.30, considering the potential overlap.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This would be estimated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q, leading to an estimate of around 0.80, reflecting a high likelihood that at least one of these events will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not P)**: This is a bit tricky since if Musk makes a statement but doesn't show up, it would depend on Q's probability when not considering P. I'd estimate this at around 0.20, reflecting the possibility of a statement without attendance.

8. **Q_given_P (Q given P occurs)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement might increase, so I'd estimate this probability higher, around 0.70.

Overall, I will ensure that the probabilities respect the consistency rules provided, particularly focusing on the relationships between P and Q and their complements.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (b) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, and not through speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements. The question resolves as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: This does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after the date. If Trump is removed or blocked and then reinstated such that on July 15th he is not removed or blocked, the question resolves negatively.

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". The question solely determines by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several questions related to Elon Musk's potential attendance and actions at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question directly addresses Musk's attendance. The probability estimate for P is influenced by factors such as Musk's past attendance at similar events, his public interest in Bitcoin, and any announcements made leading up to the conference.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, and its probability will be directly related to P. If P is high, not_P will be low, and vice versa.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is similar to P, and they should have the same probability since they are asking about the same event from slightly different angles.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is independent of P but could be correlated. Musk’s history of public statements about Bitcoin could influence this probability. 

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability is dependent on both P and Q being true. If either P or Q is low, P_and_Q will also be low. 

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is a broader question that combines the probabilities of P and Q. It should be higher than either P or Q alone, but must also adhere to the consistency rules.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not_P is true?)**: This question examines the scenario where Musk makes a public statement but does not attend the conference. The probability would depend on how likely it is for Musk to make a statement without attending.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P is true, will Q also be true?)**: This conditional probability assesses the likelihood of Q occurring if P is already established as true. Given Musk's tendency to make statements when present, this probability could be higher than Q alone.

**Independence and Relationships**: P and Q are not independent; Musk's attendance could influence his likelihood of making a statement. Therefore, the probabilities of these events must be carefully estimated to ensure they align with the consistency rules.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, or (b) Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The resolution is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, and not who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

In forecasting the probabilities for the events related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I will consider the relationships between the different questions. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question hinges on Musk's attendance, which can be influenced by various factors such as his schedule, interest in Bitcoin, or the conference's relevance. 

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, and thus it should be calculated as 1 - P. Given that the events are binary, if P has a certain probability, not_P will have a complementary probability. 

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially similar to P, as it asks about the likelihood of attendance. Therefore, it should have a probability close to that of P.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question can be somewhat independent of P, as Musk could make a statement without being physically present. However, the likelihood of him making a statement might increase if he is present, which indicates a potential correlation.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events happening together will depend on the individual probabilities of P and Q. Since both events are related (Musk's attendance could lead to a statement), this probability will be lower than either individual probability.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This rule states that at least one of the events must happen. Given the relationship between P and Q, this probability should be higher than either individual probability but must also respect the constraints of the total probability.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur and not P?)**: This situation is possible if Musk makes a statement without attending. Thus, the probability should be calculated considering Q while ensuring it does not contradict the attendance probability. 

8. **Q_given_P (Will Q occur given that P occurs?)**: This conditional probability should reflect that if Musk is present, the likelihood of him making a statement increases, so it should be higher than the probability of Q alone.

In summary, the probabilities must align with these relationships while adhering to the consistency rules. The probabilities for P and not_P must sum to 1, while P_and_Q must respect the bounds defined by P and Q, and so on. I will ensure the estimates reflect these relationships accurately.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

In this case, we are evaluating a series of events related to Elon Musk's potential attendance and statements regarding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The main events are:

1. **P**: Whether Elon Musk will show up at the conference.
2. **not_P**: Whether he will not show up at the conference.
3. **para_P**: This is essentially a rephrased version of P, asking if there is a chance he will attend.
4. **Q**: Whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference.
5. **P_and_Q**: This combines both P and Q, meaning both events must occur.
6. **P_or_Q**: This asks whether at least one of the two events (P or Q) will occur.
7. **Q_and_not_P**: This checks if Q occurs while not P occurs, meaning he makes a statement without attending.
8. **Q_given_P**: This is a conditional question asking if he will make a statement given that he does attend.

### Reasoning for Probability Estimates:
- **P (Attendance)**: Given Elon Musk's high-profile status and previous involvement in Bitcoin discussions, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend the conference. I might set this around 0.60.
- **not_P**: This is simply the complement of P, calculated as 1 - P, which would be 0.40.
- **para_P**: Since this is essentially the same as P, I would keep it at 0.60 as well.
- **Q (Public Statement)**: Given Musk's history of making statements about Bitcoin, I would estimate this at 0.70.
- **P_and_Q**: This would be the joint probability of both events occurring, which I would estimate conservatively, perhaps at around 0.42, considering the overlap.
- **P_or_Q**: The probability that at least one of these events occurs would be higher than either of the individual probabilities, perhaps around 0.80.
- **Q_and_not_P**: If he makes a statement without attending, I would estimate this at around 0.15, as it is less likely but still possible.
- **Q_given_P**: If he attends, I would expect a high probability that he also makes a statement, perhaps around 0.85.

### Independence and Relationships:
- The events P and Q are not entirely independent; his attendance may influence whether he makes a statement. This is reflected in the conditional probabilities and joint probabilities.
- The estimates need to adhere to the consistency rules, ensuring that they align mathematically across the different scenarios.

question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This is a direct prediction based on the likelihood of his attendance at the conference. Factors influencing this could include his past involvement in similar events, public interest, and potential announcements leading up to the event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P and should be calculated as 1 - P.

5. **P_and_Q (Both show up and make a statement)**: This probability will be lower than either P or Q alone since it requires both events to occur simultaneously. It can be calculated using the multiplication rule if P and Q are independent.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Public statement without attendance)**: This probability considers the scenario where Musk makes a statement but does not attend. It requires careful consideration of the independence of these events.

8. **Q_given_P (Public statement given attendance)**: This is a conditional probability that can be influenced by the fact that if Musk attends, he may be more likely to make a statement regarding Bitcoin.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President by July 26, 2024? (b) Joe Biden drops out of the race before July 20, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. The primary resolution source for this component will be official information from the US government, with a consensus of credible reporting as a secondary source.

(b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. The resolution source for this component will be whether Biden drops out or is unable to continue the race by the specified date and time.

In this scenario, the questions revolve around Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key events are whether he shows up at the conference (P), whether he does not show up (not_P), whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin (Q), and combinations of these events.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This event is likely influenced by his past attendance at similar events and current public interest in Bitcoin. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency space, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complementary event to P. If I estimate P at 0.65, then not_P should be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is effectively the same as P, so it should also be around 0.65.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: Given his history of making statements about Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability of him making a statement during this event, perhaps around 0.60.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: For this to happen, he needs to both attend and make a statement. Assuming some degree of correlation between P and Q (i.e., if he attends, he’s likely to make a statement), I estimate this at around 0.40.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This combines the probabilities of P and Q while considering their overlap. Using the formula for the union of two events, I estimate this at around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This scenario is possible if he makes a statement but does not show up at the conference. I estimate this at around 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Probability of Q given P)**: If he shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I might estimate this at around 0.80, reflecting that showing up increases the chances of him making a statement.

In summary, the relationships among these probabilities must respect the consistency rules provided. For example, the sum of P and not_P must equal 1, and the probabilities of combinations must respect the limits set by the individual probabilities.

question.title: Will either Kamala Harris become President or Acting President by July 26, 2024, or will Biden drop out before July 20, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if either of the following occurs: (a) Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET, based on official information from the US government or a consensus of credible reporting; (b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. If neither event occurs, this question will resolve to "No."

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Elon Musk's history with Bitcoin and his tendency to engage with the community, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that he will show up at the conference. I would assign a probability of around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so it would be approximately 1 - P, which gives us 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given his influence and the importance of Bitcoin discussions, I would estimate a slightly lower probability for this, around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: Musk shows up and makes a statement?)**: The probability of both events occurring would be less than or equal to the individual probabilities. I would estimate this at around 0.30.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either occur: Musk shows up or makes a statement?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, so I would estimate it at around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: Musk makes a statement and does not show up?)**: This scenario is less likely because if he makes a statement, he would likely be present. I would estimate this at around 0.10.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will he make a statement?)**: If he is present, the likelihood of him making a statement increases, so I would estimate this at around 0.70.

In summary, the probabilities reflect a reasonable expectation of Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, considering his past behaviors and the context of the event. Each probability estimate follows the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between P, Q, and their complements and combinations.

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

For this set of questions regarding Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, I will assess the probabilities based on the relationships between the events described.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is a binary event where the likelihood depends on various factors such as Musk's interest in Bitcoin and his schedule. Given his previous involvement in Bitcoin discussions, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain probability, not_P will be 1 minus that probability.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is essentially the same as P, so they should have the same probability. 

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference)**: This is likely independent of P, as he could make a statement without attending. However, his attendance could influence the probability of him making a statement.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability will depend on both P and Q. If both events are independent, I can multiply their probabilities, but I need to ensure they are not overly dependent as well.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This will be calculated using the inclusion-exclusion principle, ensuring that I account for any overlap between P and Q.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happens but P does not)**: This event can occur if Musk makes a statement without attending. This probability should be lower than Q, as it requires a specific condition.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability. If Musk attends, the likelihood of him making a statement may increase, so I need to adjust this estimate accordingly.

In summary, I will assign probabilities based on reasonable assumptions about Musk's behavior, ensuring that the consistency rules apply, particularly those concerning complements, independence, and conditional relationships.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating a series of predictions regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key questions are whether he will show up, whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin, and the relationships between these events. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: The probability of this event will be influenced by Musk's history of attending similar events and his public interest in Bitcoin. Given that this is a major conference, I estimate a moderate to high probability of 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P should be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it should also be 0.65.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This may be influenced by the context of the conference and his engagement with the Bitcoin community. Given his tendency to comment on Bitcoin, I estimate this at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This requires both events to happen. I estimate this at 0.45, which reflects a reasonable likelihood of both occurring together.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is a union of the two events. I calculate this as P + Q - P_and_Q = 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.45 = 0.90.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This is a bit tricky, as it implies Musk makes a statement but does not show up. I estimate this at 0.15, reflecting a lower likelihood of this scenario.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P occurs)**: This is a conditional probability. If he shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I estimate this at 0.80.

question.title: Will both Nikki Haley and Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Nikki Haley and Glenn Youngkin are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating various questions regarding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. Each question relates to his potential attendance and statements about Bitcoin, which allows us to establish connections between the probabilities of these events.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This probability will depend on factors like his schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and past attendance at similar events.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P, meaning if P is high, not_P will be low, and vice versa.

3. **para_P (Chance of Elon Musk attending)**: This is expected to be similar to P as it is essentially asking the same question in a different format.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This probability is influenced by his public persona and willingness to discuss Bitcoin, regardless of his attendance.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This will be lower than either P or Q alone since it requires both conditions to be met. If both probabilities are high, then this should still be a reasonable estimate.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability should be higher than both P and Q individually because it allows for either event to satisfy the condition.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This scenario is plausible if Musk makes a statement without attending. The probability should be relatively low compared to Q alone.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This should be a higher probability since if Musk is attending, he is more likely to make a statement about Bitcoin.

The relationships between these events will help in determining the probabilities based on the consistency rules provided. For example, if P is high, not_P will be low, and if P_and_Q is high, then both P and Q should also be reasonably high. Conversely, if P_or_Q is high, then at least one of the events is likely to occur.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

8. **Q_given_P (Given he shows up, will he make a statement)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases significantly. I would estimate this at around 0.80.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the questions regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I considered several factors. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is influenced by Musk's history of attending significant events and his interest in Bitcoin. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency community, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, so I suggest a value around 0.70.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, thus it should be calculated as 1 - P. If P is around 0.70, then not_P would be 0.30.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign it the same value of 0.70.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Musk has been known to make statements about Bitcoin, even if he doesn't attend events. Thus, I estimate this probability to be around 0.60.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This requires both events to happen. If P is 0.70 and Q is 0.60, I can estimate P_and_Q using the multiplication rule, which gives a value of approximately 0.42, assuming some independence.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Plugging in the values should yield a result that respects the boundaries of probability.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P?)**: This requires Q to happen while P does not. If Q is 0.60 and not_P is 0.30, I would estimate this to be lower, perhaps around 0.18, considering the overlap.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability. If P is high, I would expect Q to also be relatively high, so I would suggest a value around 0.75.

Overall, these estimates must adhere to the consistency rules provided. I will ensure that the estimates align with the mathematical relationships defined by the consistency rules, checking for overlaps and ensuring that the probability estimates do not exceed 1 or fall below 0.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, and will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is closely related to P and likely has a similar probability since it is essentially asking the same thing. I would estimate this at 0.65 as well.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event's probability may be slightly higher than P, as Musk could comment on Bitcoin even if he doesn’t show up at the conference. Thus, I would estimate Q at approximately 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability depends on both P and Q being true. Given that both events are somewhat independent but positively correlated, I would estimate this at around 0.50.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability is higher than either P or Q alone, as it includes both possibilities. Hence, I would estimate P_or_Q at 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This is a more complex relationship since it requires Q to be true while P is false. I would estimate this at a lower probability, around 0.20, since it relies on Musk making a statement but not attending the conference.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability is likely high, as if Musk attends, the chances of him making a statement about Bitcoin are increased. I would estimate this at 0.85.

In summary, the relationships between these probabilities are interconnected, and I ensured that they adhered to the consistency rules provided. I took care to ensure that the estimates remained within logical bounds and reflected the dependencies and independencies of each event.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following occurs:

(a) Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

The question will resolve as "No" if neither condition (a) nor condition (b) is met.

In evaluating the probability estimates for the various questions regarding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I will consider both the independent events and their logical relationships. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This is a direct question about Musk's attendance. Factors influencing this could include his public interest in Bitcoin and past attendance at similar events. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P, so it will simply be 1 - P. If P is high, not_P will be low, and vice versa. 

3. **para_P (Chance of attendance)**: This is similar to P but framed as a chance. It should align closely with P, as the chance of attendance is essentially the same as the prediction of attendance. 

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin)**: This question is independent of P, as Musk could make a statement regardless of whether he shows up. However, past behavior suggests that his attendance might correlate with public statements. 

5. **P_and_Q (Both show up and make a statement)**: This probability will be lower than either P or Q alone, as it requires both conditions to be true. It can be calculated using the multiplication rule for independent events if deemed independent, or adjusted based on observed correlations. 

6. **P_or_Q (Either show up or make a statement)**: This will be higher than either P or Q alone, as it captures the likelihood of at least one of the events occurring. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Statement without attendance)**: This situation is possible if Musk makes a statement without attending. It will depend on how likely it is for him to make a statement without being present. 

8. **Q_given_P (Statement given attendance)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement may increase, so this probability will likely be higher than Q alone. 

Overall, I will ensure that my probability estimates reflect these relationships and adhere to the consistency rules outlined. I will also check that the estimates for P and not_P sum to 1, and that the relationships between P, Q, and their combinations hold true according to the logical rules.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).
